Honeywell Hopewell Facility

Executive Summary

Introduction

The Honeywell Hopewell facility is a manufacturing complex located in Hopewell, VA. It is a part of the Specialty Materials business unit of Honeywell International Inc. Two distinct businesses operate on the site and within the larger Specialty Materials business unit; Honeywell Nylon Inc. and Honeywell Chemicals. These business units are documented in Honeywell's RMP plan as Process #1 and Process #2, respectively.

Honeywell International is a $23 billion diversified technology and manufacturing leader, serving customers worldwide with aerospace products and services; control technologies for buildings, homes and industry; automotive products; turbochargers; and specialty materials.  Headquartered in Morris Township, N.J., Honeywell International's shares are traded on the New York, London, Chicago and Pacific Stock Exchanges. 

Honeywell Specialty Materials, also based in Morris Township, N.J., is a business group of Honeywell International and a global leader in providing high-performance specialty materials such as fluorocarbons, specialty films, advanced fibers, customized research chemicals and intermediates.

Honeywell Nylon Inc. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Honeywell International.  Honeywell Nylon is a fully integrated producer of Nylon 6 carpet fibers and resins, automotive and textile fibers, specialty polymers and chemical intermediates. Honeywell Nylon is based in Charlotte, N.C., and has manufacturing facilities in the Eastern U.S, Canada and China.

Honeywell Chemicals, integrated within Honeywell's Specialty Materials business, provides oxime-chemistry products to agricultural and specialty chemicals markets.

Health, Safety and Environment/Responsible Care

Honeywell is committed to managing health, safety and the environment as a core business value. The company also integrates health, safety and environmental management into all aspects of our businesses as a com

mployees at the Honeywell Hopewell facility are committed to the safe and reliable operation of the plant in a manner that safeguards life, health, property and the environment.  The process safety and risk management initiatives are implemented as proactive approaches to minimize the potential for accidental releases.  Policies and procedures have been implemented to guide the plant to meet the requirements of the federal mandates.  

Each of the seven chemicals on the EPA list at the Honeywell Hopewell facility have been evaluated based on EPA's guidelines.  Specific information related to each chemical is supplied in our risk management plan, available from the EPA.  In all of these cases, there are numerous safety devices to prevent and/or reduce the chance of a release occurring.  Examples of these devices include:
* Remote operated shutoff valves
* Remote detectors
* Continuous process monitoring 
* Containment dikes 

Accidental releases are also minimized by safe plant design, frequent equipment modernization, computer-controlled alarm and shutdown interlock systems, and end-of-pipe control systems when appropriate.

Process Safety Information

The Hopewell facility has established specific guidelines and procedures for compiling and maintaining written information for the chemical processes we operate.  Specific responsibilities for maintaining this process safety information have been identified and assigned to qualified individuals.  The facility's hazard communication program communicates the health and environmental effects of chemicals to our employees.  We also maintain comprehensive evaluations of the process chemistry and operating conditions of all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

We analyze each chemical process utilizing a method designed to evaluate the process for hazards such as fire, chemical release, and explosions.  The utilization of proven hazard analysis techniques has been applied at the Hopewell facility for m

petitive advantage in achieving profitable growth and accelerated productivity.

Honeywell participates in the Responsible Care program of the American Chemistry Council. Established in 1988, Responsible Care is a voluntary program focused on achieving improvements in environmental, health and safety performance beyond levels required by the U.S. government.

In addition to detailing practices for the safe use of materials and requiring audits, the Responsible Care initiative requires its member and partner companies to develop mechanisms for outreach within the communities in which they operate. Community Advisory Panels (CAP) serve as important links between chemical facilities and their neighboring communities. 

The Honeywell facility is an active participant in the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and in the Hopewell Community Industrial Panel (HCIP), a CAP. Both organizations provide for ongoing cooperation and information-sharing with city leaders, citizens, and industrial neighbors on emergency planning , process safety, and related issues. 

Honeywell Hopewell Facility

The Honeywell Hopewell facility employees nearly 800 people and is the largest Caprolactam manufacturing site in the world. Ammonium sulfate, a granular fertilizer high in nitrogen and sulfur content, is produced as a co-product and is sold and distributed globally. 

The site requires three main raw materials (natural gas, sulfur and phenol) to produce a variety of other products in addition to caprolactam and ammonium sulfate.  These include:
* Cyclohexanone 
* Cyclohexanol
* Adipic acid 
* Specialty chemicals:
* Aldicarb oxime 
* Acetaldehyde oxime 
* Methylethyl ketoxime 
* Other oximes
These products are sold to other industrial customers for use in manufacturing various consumer products such as fertilizers, tennis shoes, lingerie, videotapes, paints and shellacs.

Of the many chemicals at the Hopewell plant, seven are identified on the EPA list of highl

y hazardous chemicals. They are stored at the site in quantities exceeding the specified threshold quantities as defined by the EPA's RMP rule. They are:
* Anhydrous ammonia 			Threshold Quantity - 10,000 Lbs.
* Chlorine 					Threshold Quantity -    2500 Lbs.
* Methyl mercaptan 			Threshold Quantity - 10,000 Lbs.
* Methyltrichlorosilane 			Threshold Quantity -   5,000 Lbs.
* Oleum 					Threshold Quantity - 10,000 Lbs.
* Ammonia solution (22%)		Threshold Quantity - 20,000 Lbs.
* Acetaldehyde 				Threshold Quantity - 10,000 Lbs.

These chemicals, along with other chemicals manufactured or consumed, are stored in a variety of tanks and vessels specially designed for them and their varied processing steps.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of the Honeywell Hopewell facility to operate a safe and environmentally sound manufacturing site by identifying and controlling health, safety, and environmental risks related to its operations; by designing its processes to protect people, property and the environment; by conducting and continually reviewing and improving programs for safety, health and environmental excellence; and by establishing processes to assure that all laws and regulations applicable to its operations and products are known and observed.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy associated with the plant's use of all potentially hazardous chemicals involves:
* the integration of safety devices
* technologies inherent in the design of the process
* safe operational procedures and management practices
* operator training
* the preparation and testing of site emergency response plans
* the maintenance of onsite emergency response equipment
* a professionally trained Emergency Response Brigade
* coordination of our efforts and resources with local emergency response services
* and communication with the community.


Process Safety Accident Prevention Program

Each process change or process modification undergoes rigorous technical evaluation using the highest standards of personal and community safety as the focal point.  We review the process hazard analyses on a continuing 5-year cycle so that we maintain a high degree of process safety integrity.  Each PHA uses the appropriate methodology to analyze potential hazards and their effects and provides for timely resolution of recommendations.  Recent hazard analyses have shown the need for additional redundant environmental control systems for those rare occasions when the primary control system requires preventative maintenance.  These recommended controls have been installed.

Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures are structured to cover all aspects of plant operation including startup, shutdown, normal operations, upset conditions and emergency response. Each operating area of the plant has specific operating procedures developed by those people most knowledgeable in the plant operation, including operators and area supervisors.  Other process operators and supervisors review these procedures for accuracy and consistency.  After review, the department manager verifies that they are accurate and up-to-date and annually certifies the operating procedures.  Operators work closely with process engineers as process modifications take place to make sure the operating procedures include information relating to the process changes.

Training

Besides standard operating procedures, the Hopewell facility has developed extensive training materials to support the development of individuals into highly trained and qualified process operators. These training manuals have been developed by the operators themselves and cover their expansive knowledge from years of on-the-job service.  The

training program is supported with computer based training modules and extensive hands-on training by qualified area trainers. Operators are trained on computers that simulate real-life plant situations before they can qualify to work in the operating areas of the plant.  The Hopewell plant operators are required to complete a multi-year training program before becoming fully qualified.  To assist in documenting and tracking employee training, we have installed a software program which involves self-directed learning, online information databases and integrated procedures and training manuals. 

Mechanical Integrity

Mechanical integrity of plant equipment is another way we reduce the probability and consequences of accidental releases.  We assure that equipment is fit for its intended service.  Extensive on-going inspection programs are key to maintaining the process equipment. Guidelines and procedures have been developed and are followed by employees performing the inspections.  These individuals are trained and qualified to analyze data and provide operations with timely information for continued safe equipment operation.  Quality assurance of new equipment, processes and spare parts provide additional confidence that the equipment containing the process chemicals will perform as designed.  For example, process vessels holding chemicals are inspected/evaluated on a preset timetable using visual, ultrasonic thickness testing, and/or other non-destructive techniques as needed.  Based on the results of these tests, appropriate actions are taken to assure that the vessels continue to be fit-for-service. 

Management of Change

Managing change is a key activity associated with process safety and risk management.  Detailed procedural steps have been developed to provide guidance for operations personnel in making necessary process and mechanical changes to maintain a safe plant and achieve a high level of performance.  Multi-departmental approvals are require

d before proceeding with the requested change.  This management of change process incorporates:
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedure updates
* Mechanical integrity review
* Pre-startup safety reviews
* Audits to ensure that any process or mechanical change maintains our high level of safe performance
* Operator training

Pre-Startup Review

We perform safety checks to ensure that all process safety precautions have been taken prior to starting up a new or modified process. These checklists serve as a reminder and give guidance for support groups as they evaluate the requested changes.  The support groups provide written documentation to the owning departments verifying that the requested change has been thoroughly reviewed and will be implemented in a safe manner.  

Compliance Audits

Compliance audits serve as verification that the process safety and risk management programs are functioning as per the federal mandates.  Formal, comprehensive audits are performed at least every three years on the entire prevention component of RMP (Process Safety Management).  Targeted audits are performed on a more frequent basis to maintain an on-going level of process safety. A monthly  safety audit program often includes PSM elements as the primary topic. The Honeywell corporate audit team provides an additional level of evaluation for enhanced compliance.

Incident Investigation

The facility has specific procedures for addressing unplanned events. These procedures include a detailed incident investigation requirement for major, minor and potential incidents.   The team approach is used to investigate the incident and includes appropriate personnel, including hourly employees.  Analysis techniques include structured root cause analysis and a system to track recommendations to resolution.  

Employee Participation

The Hopewell plant has several teams and committees from the plant leader level to the wage roll employees structured to focus on sa

fety and process safety activities throughout the plant.  Many examples have been identified in the elements of process safety being discussed in this section of the executive summary.  One key committee is the Health, Safety and Environmental Council.  This council of plant management and hourly leaders develops and implements safety and environmental goals.

Hot Work Permits

The purpose of the hot work permit at the Hopewell facility is to regulate the use of equipment capable of igniting flammable or combustible material.  Due to the variety of flammables used in the plant, it is mandatory that any hot work be thoroughly reviewed and strict adherence to the procedure is required. A permit system with very detailed and specific check-off requirements is used in order to achieve our goal of safe hot work.

Contractors

The Hopewell plant's contractor safety program encompasses contractor screening for suitability to perform to Honeywell standards. Contractors working on-site meet the strict safety requirements including: 
* A comprehensive safety orientation
* Detailed qualification and training documentation
* Insurance requirements
* Hazard communication program
* Formal audit system
* An accident-investigation procedure
 
Five-Year Accident History

The Honeywell Hopewell facility has not experienced any releases that resulted in an EPA-defined RMP off-site consequence in the past five years.

Emergency Response Plan

The site's written Emergency Response Plan underwent a thorough review and revision process in 2002. The plan is now more comprehensive and more accessible for use during an incident. In addition, a significant investment was made in a new, state-of-the-art Emergency Operations Center (EOC), complete with video monitoring capabilities. 

The Hopewell plant emergency response plan is designed to:
* Enable the plant to effectively cope with a plant emergency
* Reduce the hazards of injury to plant personnel and hold to a mi

nimum damage to plant property and equipment
* Form an organization capable of dealing with immediate needs during and after an emergency 
* Minimize the impact of any incident on the environment and surrounding area

The plan requires alerting site employees via an audible alarm system and a Public Address (PA) system. If warranted, the community will be notified through the local police and fire departments, including activation of the Hopewell Emergency Notification System (HENS) or other communication tools. Evacuation procedures are included in the emergency response plan.  Each functional department head is charged to focus on the safety of the employees and local citizenry.  Communication is provided via a specialized radio service. Site leaders, including the incident commander, can review the situation and coordinate directly with other emergency response agencies.  Direct 2-way radio links are in place to quickly notify local school systems and media sources.  

The facility has its own emergency response brigade comprised of approximately 75 trained, qualified, and certified emergency response individuals.  These responders receive additional training in chemical plant emergency response and many have been trained at nationally known emergency response schools in Texas, Nevada and South Carolina.  The effectiveness of these plans and responses to incidents are reviewed and tested annually through drills involving the brigade and local police, fire, rescue and other emergency service personnel. The brigade receives periodic training e.g., tabletop drills, hands on exercises, and classroom instruction throughout the year. 

Changes to Improve Safety

Employees and management at the Honeywell Hopewell facility continually strive to improve safety of the operations. Site employees benchmark similar industrial companies and other industry leaders, seeking opportunities to apply new technologies and methods. 

An enhanced PHA process helps managemen

t identify and correct potential hazards, as well as ensure proper documentation. An electronic Corrective Action Tracking system facilitates timely and effective resolutions of any needed corrective actions.

The latest dispersion modeling software and techniques is utilized to better determine the results of potential accidental releases. This also ensures a proper prioritization of recommendations from PHAs.

Enhancements to employee protection systems in control rooms have taken place. These enhancements provide additional protection for the operators and other employees on the site. An active program directed toward further improvements in this area is in place.

A comprehensive incident investigation program enhances our ability to avoid recurrence of incidents. We have trained approximately 180 salaried and hourly employees in root cause analysis techniques.  This investigative system is a methodology that drives towards removing and correcting the causes of equipment and procedural failures.  It is widely used to help improve our level of safety and environmental performance.

We continually reevaluate the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  For example, we recently determined that a less-toxic chemical (bromine) could be substituted for chlorine in the treatment of our closed loop cooling towers. As a result, one-ton chlorine cylinders have been removed from two of our operating areas, thus eliminating the chemical entirely from the Caprolactam process (Process #1).
